<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='1886 March 10 No Quorum'><u>1886 March 10 No Quorum</u></span></p>
<p><u>March 10, 1886</u></p>
<p>The Monthly Meeting was notified to be<span class='line-break'> </span>held on Wednesday, March 10, 1886, at 2:30<span class='line-break'> </span>o'clock, P.M.</p>
<p><u>No quorum was present.</u></p>
<p>Lewis G. Farmer</p>
<p>Secretary.</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='April 7 Special Meeting'><u>April 7 Special Meeting</u></span></p>
<p><u>April 7, 1886</u></p>
<p>A Special Meeting of the Board of Trustees<span class='line-break'> </span>was held as notified, on Wednesday, April 7,<span class='line-break'> </span>1886, at 2:30 o'clock. P.M.</p>
<p>Present, the President, and Messrs. Choate,<span class='line-break'> </span>Browne, Rice, Payson, Wolcott and Jones.</p>
<p>Voted - That the reading of the records of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Meeting of February 11, and of March 10 be<span class='line-break'> </span>dispensed with.</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='Sales of Land.'><u>Sales of Land.</u></span></p>
<p>The Secretary presented Statements^245. 246^ of<span class='line-break'> </span>Sales of Land from February 11 to April 7.</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='Treasurer&apos;s Quarterly Report.'><u>Treasurer's Quarterly Report.</u></span></p>
<p>The Treasurer having presented his Report^247.^<span class='line-break'> </span>for the Quarter ending March 31, the same<span class='line-break'> </span>was referred to the Committee on Finance.</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='Monthly Bills.'><u>Monthly Bills.</u></span></p>
<p>The President reported that he had ex<span class='line-break'></span>amined and approved the Schedule of Monthly<span class='line-break'> </span>Bills of March 10, $3039.56, and that the same<span class='line-break'> </span>had been thereupon paid by the Treasurer.<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1135622">
<h3><a name="page-1135622">Trustees Records, Vol. 6, 1875, page 380</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>The Schedule of April 7, showing a total of <span class='line-break'> </span>$3652.44 was presented:<span class='line-break'> </span>Voted, That upon approval by the President,<span class='line-break'> </span>payment thereof be made by the Tresurer.</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='Contracts Perpetual Care'>Contracts Perpetual Care</span><span class='line-break'> </span>The Committee on Lots recommeneded the<span class='line-break'> </span>following contracts for perpetual care, all of<span class='line-break'> </span>which were approved by the Board: -<span class='line-break'> </span>Lot 393 *Mary Prichard by Heirs $325<span class='line-break'> </span>Lot 1050  *Oren Peck by Heirs 275.<span class='line-break'> </span>Lot 1324 Mrs. Alice Mann  375.<span class='line-break'> </span>Lot 2207  *Edward P. Bancroft by<span class='line-break'> </span>Exr's of Estate of Widow   850.<span class='line-break'> </span>Lot 2900 + 2901  *John L. Gardner  by  Exr's  2500.<span class='line-break'> </span>Lot 3423  *Wm. W. Tucker by  Exr's    600.<span class='line-break'> </span>Lot 3518 + 3519  * Charles Thompson by Jr's   550.</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='New Offices'>New Offices</span><span class='line-break'> </span>Voted. That a location in Pemberton<span class='line-break'> </span>Square for the new offices of the Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>is desirable, and that the matter of securing<span class='line-break'> </span>such new offices be intrusted to the com<span class='line-break'></span>mittee previously appointed consisting<span class='line-break'> </span>of the President and Messrs. Choate and<span class='line-break'> </span>Browne, with full powers.</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='Statue of Dr. Nathaniel Bowditch'>Statue of Dr. Nathaniel Bowditch</span><span class='line-break'> </span>The President presented the following letter<span class='line-break'> </span>in regard to the Statue of Dr. Nathaniel Bowditch<span class='line-break'> </span>28 State St., Boston<span class='line-break'> </span>March 13, 1886<span class='line-break'> </span>James W. Lovering, Esq., Superintendent +c., <span class='line-break'> </span>Dear Sir:</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1135623">
<h3><a name="page-1135623">Trustees Records, Vol. 6, 1875, page 381</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>The Statue of the late Dr. Nathaniel<span class='line-break'> </span>Bowditch, now standing in Mount Auburn Cemetery,<span class='line-break'> </span>is in a very unsatisfactory condition owing to cracks<span class='line-break'> </span>having appeared in the bronze and to the metal<span class='line-break'> </span>scaling off. A report made by Mr. F. H. Bartlett,<span class='line-break'> </span>a competent expert, advises that there is no<span class='line-break'> </span>use in trying to repair the statue, and that a<span class='line-break'> </span>new one should be cast.<span class='line-break'> </span>The children of Dr. Bowditch will<span class='line-break'> </span>very gladly bear the expense of casting a new<span class='line-break'> </span>statue, and of placing it in Mt. Auburn; and<span class='line-break'> </span>would like permission to remove the present statue<span class='line-break'> </span>from its pedestal for the purpose of sending it<span class='line-break'> </span>to Europe and having a new cast made from <span class='line-break'> </span>it as a model, which will be done as quickly<span class='line-break'> </span>as possible.<span class='line-break'> </span>Will you be kind enough to<span class='line-break'> </span>obtain permissions from the Trustees for the re<span class='line-break'></span>moval of the Statue for the above purpose?<span class='line-break'> </span>Very respectfully yours,<span class='line-break'> </span>Charles P. Bowditch<span class='line-break'> </span>J. Ingersoll Bowditch<span class='line-break'> </span>Henry J. Bowditch<span class='line-break'> </span>William J. Bowditch<span class='line-break'> </span>Mary J. B. Dixwell<span class='line-break'> </span>Eliza B. J. B. Dixwell<span class='line-break'> </span>The letter having been read by the President<span class='line-break'> </span>he stated to the Board that he has granted</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1135624">
<h3><a name="page-1135624">Trustees Records, Vol. 6, 1875, page 382</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>382</p>
<p>the permission therein asked, and it was<span class='line-break'> </span>thereupon voted. That this action of the<span class='line-break'> </span>President be approved by the Board, and that<span class='line-break'> </span>permission be granted for the removal of the<span class='line-break'> </span>statue for the purposes set forth in the<span class='line-break'> </span>said letter.</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='Ancient Watercourse in Cemetery.'><u>Ancient Watercourse in Cemetery.</u></span></p>
<p>The President presented a letter^249^ fromt eh Mayor<span class='line-break'> </span>of Cambridge in regard to the stoppage of an alleged<span class='line-break'> </span>ancient watercourse in the Cemetery, which it<span class='line-break'> </span>was claimed caused an overflow of surface water<span class='line-break'> </span>in the Belmont district of that City. Permission<span class='line-break'> </span>was requested to enter the Cemetery and clean<span class='line-break'> </span>said watercourse without expense to the Corpo<span class='line-break'></span>ration and without damage to its property<span class='line-break'> </span>or that of the Proprietors. The President<span class='line-break'> </span>stated that he had been unable to ascertain<span class='line-break'> </span>that any such watercourse had ever existed,<span class='line-break'> </span>and that he had visited the Cemetery with<span class='line-break'> </span>the Mayor, and examined the locality where<span class='line-break'> </span>said watercourse was supposed to have been;<span class='line-break'> </span>[<del>and had conferred with him on the subject.</del>]<span class='line-break'> </span>The matter was discussed to some extent,<span class='line-break'> </span>and it was voted that the action of</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='Committee Appointed.'><u>Committee Appointed.</u></span></p>
<p>the President be approved, and that he and<span class='line-break'> </span>Mr. Choate be appointed a committee, with full<span class='line-break'> </span>power, to do whatever they might think desirable<span class='line-break'> </span>in the way of perpetuating testimony in<span class='line-break'> </span>regard to the existence of such watercourse,</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1135625">
<h3><a name="page-1135625">Trustees Records, Vol. 6, 1875, page 383</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>383</p>
<p>if any, or otherwise, and that the whole subject<span class='line-break'> </span>be referred to said Committee.</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='Regular Meeting Dispensed with.'><u>Regular Meeting Dispensed with.</u></span></p>
<p>Voted that the regular monthly meeting<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Board for the present month of April<span class='line-break'> </span>be dispensed with.</p>
<p>Dissolved,</p>
<p>Lewis G. Farmer,</p>
<p>Secretary.</p>
<p>[line deleted from previous page continued onto this page]</p>
<p>that the Mayor did not press the question of the rights<span class='line-break'> </span>of the city to enter and clean out the obstructions, any fur<span class='line-break'></span>ther, but simply requested (waiving all right) the privi<span class='line-break'></span>lege of cleaning out the drain as it at present existed<span class='line-break'> </span>at the expense of teh city, which request the President<span class='line-break'> </span>had granted on condition that the work be done under<span class='line-break'> </span>the direction of the Superintendent of the Cemetery in such<span class='line-break'> </span>manner as not to interfere with any of the Lots under which<span class='line-break'> </span>the drain was constructed. [Written by me as a part of the record<span class='line-break'> </span>of said meeting. L.G. Farmer, Sec'y.]<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1135626">
<h3><a name="page-1135626">Trustees Records, Vol. 6, 1875, page 384</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>384</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='1886 May 12 No Quorum'><u>1886 May 12 No Quorum</u></span></p>
<p><u>May 12, 1886</u></p>
<p>The Monthly Meeting was notified to be<span class='line-break'> </span>held on Wednesday, May 12, 1886, at 2:30 P.M.</p>
<p><u>No quorum was present.</u></p>
<p>Lewis G. Farmer,</p>
<p>Secretary.</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='1886 June 9 No Quorum'><u>1886 June 9 No Quorum</u></span></p>
<p><u>June 9, 1886</u></p>
<p>The Monthly Meeting was notified to<span class='line-break'> </span>be held on Wednesday, June 9, 1886, at<span class='line-break'> </span>2:30 P.M.</p>
<p><u>No quorum was present</u></p>
<p>Lewis G. Farmer,</p>
<p>Secretary.</p>
<p>End of Volume VI.</p>
<p>L.G.F., Sec'y.<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1135627">
<h3><a name="page-1135627">Trustees Records, Vol. 6, 1875, page 388</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>New Book<span class='line-break'> </span>Masters Records<span class='line-break'> </span>No 7<span class='line-break'> </span>in safe ready <span class='line-break'> </span>for use<span class='line-break'> </span>[?] <span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
